name: Mexico City
fun_fact: Fun fact: Mexico City is built on top of the ancient Aztec capital Tenochtitlan, which was constructed on a lake - this means the entire city is slowly sinking, but locals joke that the food is so good, they'd happily sink with it rather than leave.

hero_dishes.name: Cochinita Pibil Tacos
hero_dishes.description: Slow-roasted pork marinated in achiote and citrus, wrapped in banana leaves, served in soft corn tortillas with pickled onions
hero_dishes.origin_story: This Yucatecan specialty has been adopted by Mexico City and perfected at spots like El Turix, where there's no seating - you order at the window and take your tacos to go, just like locals have done for generations
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Turix (walk-up window, cochinita pibil is the house specialty)

hero_dishes.name: Mole Poblano
hero_dishes.description: Complex sauce with over 20 ingredients including chocolate, chilis, nuts, and spices, served over chicken
hero_dishes.origin_story: Legend says nuns in Puebla created this for a visiting archbishop, but Mexico City has made it their own. At Angelopolitano, they serve authentic Puebla-style mole that takes days to prepare
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Angelopolitano (Puebla 371, Roma Norte - authentic Puebla cuisine), El Cardenal

hero_dishes.name: Chile en Nogada
hero_dishes.description: Poblano chili stuffed with picadillo (meat, fruits, and spices), topped with walnut cream sauce and pomegranate seeds - red, white, and green like the Mexican flag
hero_dishes.origin_story: Created in 1821 to celebrate Mexico's independence, this dish is only available in season (August-September) when pomegranates are ripe. El Cardenal has been serving it for 40 years
hero_dishes.where_to_find: El Cardenal (40 years of history, Centro HistÃ³rico), Angelopolitano (seasonal, check availability)

hero_dishes.name: Pre-Hispanic Cuisine at Expendio de Maiz
hero_dishes.description: Dishes using ancient corn varieties and pre-Hispanic cooking techniques - served on the street when ready
hero_dishes.origin_story: Chef JesÃºs TornÃ©s works with small farmers from Guerrero state, using heirloom corn and cooking methods that predate Spanish colonization. Food arrives when it's ready, creating a reverent street food experience
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Expendio de Maiz (casual yet reverent, global attention for traditional rural cooking)

signature_drinks.name: Mezcal
signature_drinks.description: Smoky agave spirit from Oaxaca - artisanal, complex, and ceremonial
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Sipped slowly, never shot. Locals say 'para todo mal, mezcal, y para todo bien, tambiÃ©n' (for everything bad, mezcal, and for everything good, the same). Often served with orange slices and sal de gusano (worm salt)

signature_drinks.name: Atole
signature_drinks.description: Hot corn-based drink, thick and sweet, flavored with chocolate, vanilla, or fruit
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Consumed for breakfast with tamales at markets and street stalls. It's warming, filling, and has been drunk since Aztec times

food_culture_notes: El Cardenal (40 years old) emphasizes ingredient origins with seasonal menu including escamoles (ant larvae) and cod a la vizcaina
Grana in a 16th-century downtown building reinterprets traditional dishes with seasonal vegetables and seafood - recognized as one of Mexico's best
Hacienda de los Morales in an old Polanco silkworm hacienda combines historic setting with upscale traditional cooking
Roma and Condesa neighborhoods offer the best mix of traditional and modern Mexican cuisine
